bibl.title: Letter from George Miller Sternberg to Walter Reed, December 19, 1900

div1.p: Sternberg congratulates Reed on the success of his experiments. He hopes Reed can identify the parasite, and thinks it would be desirable to conduct experiments that would involve inoculation with blood from yellow fever cases.

div1.head: Letter from George Miller Sternberg to Walter Reed, December 19, 1900
div1.opener:
422
Communications on official business should be addressed “To the Surgeon General, U. S. Army, Washington, D. C.”
Subject:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
Surgeon General's Office,
Washington, December 19, 1900.
In reply refer to No._____
Major Walter Reed,
Surgeon, U. S. Army,
Camp Columbia, Quemados, Cuba.
My dear Major Reed:-
div1.p:
I was very much pleased to receive your telegrams and your letter
of December 14th and congratulate you upon the success of your experiments.
Now if you can identify the parasite the question of etiology will to a
great extent be settled. With reference to inoculations with blood of
yellow fever cases, I think it would be desirable to make some experiments.
The question is still open as to whether the parasite must pass through
the body of a mosquito in order to infect susceptible individuals. If
it is in the blood of patients in such a stage of development that the
disease can be transmitted by inoculating small quantities of blood, then
I see no good reason why the contents of the intestine should not also
contain the germ as disorganized blood is always present in fatal cases.
Having proved that the disease may be transmitted by mosquitoes there is
little reason to doubt that this is the usual way in which it is trans-
mitted; but we should not hastily conclude that it is the only way.
Please keep me informed as to the results of future experiments. I have
sent copies of your telegrams to the editor of the Philadelphia Medical
Journal, and have also given the substance of them to the Associated Press.
With kind regards to your associates, I remain,
